title: Behind the Gown and the Smile
content:
Behind the Gown and the Smile

The ward doesn’t sound the same when you’re the one trapped in the bed. For everyone else, it’s just noise—alarms, voices, wheels squeaking—but for me it was war. Every beep from the monitor felt like a countdown. Every rushed step of a nurse sounded like a judgment call: _he’s getting worse_.

Mum walked in. I smiled, weakly, because that’s what I do. That’s what she needed. I croaked out, _“Hi, mama.”_ But I already knew what she saw. That tube in my nose wasn’t just a tube—it was a confession. My body had lost the fight again. The machines were back in charge.

I was scared. Hell, I was terrified. But I couldn’t say that. Once you say it, you break the last bit of control you’ve got. So I kept it locked inside while the monitor betrayed me.

> Sometimes bravery is just **not pulling the mask off**. Sometimes it’s letting the machine do the breathing until your body remembers how.

title: The Price of Breath (Trikafta)
content:
# The Price of Breath (Trikafta)

Being on Trikafta changed me. It made me sharper, more irritable, and sometimes the people closest to me wore the shrapnel. It’s saving me, but some days it feels like it’s unmaking me too.

Before this drug, I knew how to survive CF like a brutal routine. Now the pain is different, the emotions louder, and the choices heavier. I’m learning in real time how to make peace with a medicine that gives me breath — and then charges **interest**.

I don’t want to romanticize suffering—ICU was real, the alarms were real—but I understood that battlefield. This one is new. I’m building a life on ground that still trembles, and that’s okay. New ground always does.

title: The Silence That Screams
content:
# The Silence That Screams

Some people cry out loud. Others sink without a ripple. I’ve talked about mental health a hundred times and I’ll talk about it a hundred more — not because it’s trendy, but because people are slipping through the cracks while we scroll past.

If that’s you — the quiet one — this is me saying I see you. It’s okay to be messy, to ask for help, to say _“I don’t know how to carry this.”_ You are not a burden. Your breath is allowed to take up space.

And if you don’t know the words yet, try this: _“Can you sit with me?”_ It’s enough.

title: When the Darkness Called
content:
# When the Darkness Called

The darkness was calling me again. Not like alarms or monitors — quiet, heavy, almost comforting. _Close your eyes. Let go. You’ve done enough._

But something fiercer cut through the haze: **No.** You’re not fighting for yourself anymore. Fight so the next kid sees what strength looks like.

[Learn more about CF NZ](https://www.cfnz.org.nz)

title: The Fear I Couldn’t Admit
content:
# The Fear I Couldn’t Admit

The ward was a blur of yellow gowns and clipped voices. The oximeter glowed at me: `SpO₂ 89%`. Heart `147`. Fever humming through my skin. I knew what it meant and I hated that I knew.

_“I think I have a fever,”_ I said anyway, as if naming it could tame it. The cuff squeezed my arm, the room tightened, and I tried not to listen to the beeps measuring out my fear.

I don’t remember falling asleep. I remember waking up and realizing I’d survived another round I didn’t want to fight.

title: The Nurse and the Sandwich
content:
# The Nurse and the Sandwich

She didn’t burst in like a hero. She just slipped through the door like she’d done this a hundred times. She checked the lines, the numbers, my eyes. Then she put a sandwich and a glass of water on the table.

It wasn’t a cure. It was permission to stay. I took a bite, and the room softened enough for me to choose one more hour. Sometimes that’s all the medicine you need — one more hour.

title: Behind the Smile (Extended)
content:
# Behind the Smile (Extended)

When family walks in, you learn a new language: the one where smiles mean _“I’m still here,”_ even if your lungs are arguing. The mask hides the strain and the monitors tattle, but a smile is a small rebellion. It says: **not today**.

A smile can be love. It can also be armour. Sometimes it’s both at once.

title: Holding the Line
content:
# Holding the Line

Not every day is a comeback story. Some days it’s just doing the physio, taking the meds, being kind to the nurse who’s on hour eleven, and texting back the mate who’s worried. It isn’t flashy, but it’s how you hold the line until the tide turns.

And the tide does turn. Maybe not today. But it learns your name.

title: Notes to the Quiet Kid
content:
# Notes to the Quiet Kid

You don’t have to audition for care. You don’t have to be the loudest to be the most in pain.

- If your voice shakes, that’s fine.
- If your hands shake, that’s fine.
- If all you can do is nod when someone says, _“Do you want me to stay?”_ — that’s fine too.

The point is: you’re still here. Let’s keep you here. Start with water. Start with breath. Start with saying, _“I’m not okay.”_ We can work with that.
